results.content: So far, the number 1 thing I like about this class better than others is that the instructor repeats what he has said many times. I don't think many instructors understand that this is not like school. In school you can ask a question after you get an instruction from a teacher, so they answer your question or reiterate in order for you to understand. But most instructors just throw the information at you and you are on your own. This instructor repeats things he said in previous lessons to really make you understand what he means. It is almost as if a student came in the next day and needed clarification, which is actually helpful to the whole class.

response.content: Hey Prescott! That's exactly what we were aiming for when I was building this course with Kalob. We never know when a student will watch a video and take a break, so repeating ourselves is a nice reminder. It's also great because, at least for me, I can't watch something once and just know it after that. I need to hear things more than once for it to become something I remember - we suspect lots of people work this way so we built it into the course lessons!

results.content:
He is a great teacher, with a pleasing voice.  The information itself is very good.  

Small complaints: The information needed to complete the CSS 101 project isn't covered until CSS 201.  The excuse that we should figure it out or search the internet is silly.  That is why we are watching the course to get the information.

The project for CSS 101 should have waited until the end of 201.  

Actually, I took notes the whole time for HTML 201 also and gained a lot of information but I couldn't actually do either of the first 2 projects because I only gained the necessary information later in the course!  It can lead to a sense of frustration like maybe I missed something...but no.  It is just revealed in later videos.  

This is not to take away from the course itself or its value.  The information is great and accurate and he is even entertaining at times.  

Still...if you are reading this buy the course but don't bother with the projects until the end.  Once you actually are taught the basics you can go back and complete the projects much easier.  

I am downgrading from 5 stars to 4.5 stars because of this but this is not a reflection of poor information, just poor structure to the projects. I don't like wasting any time right now as I am sacrificing important things to study.

results.content: This course was great, you learn everything about Web Development that you need to start making top-tier websites immediately. There will be things that you need to learn on your own, but there is no course that can or will teach you everything. The only improvement that I can suggest to Kalob and his team is to introduce the subject and what you are going to do for like 15-30 seconds before diving straight in. It would help people like myself who are taking notes and trying to grasp everything if we had a little summary before we start. Overall great course and I would recommend it to anyone.

results.content:
Just finished the course today. First round, cuz it's so dense surely I'll have to take one or more round of it.

What about that?

The course is great, and Kalob is a super nice dude.

A lot of topics being covered in more than 40 hrs (but it tooks like about x2 if you plan to do exercies and projects, or even more, if you want to do them well).

I am not very sure it fit for absolute beginners, I mean, I wont go from zero to django dev but in any way Kalob explain everything from the ground up.

All the libs and frameworks are up to date 2021 and believe me this is not so common in Udemy nowadays.

Buying the course you'll also get access to a facebook private group and a discord server, where people literally run to help you when asking questions. That's terrific.

A thing I would have improved? I feel the course is somehow "backend-ish" oriented. The part of web design in its core term is lacking, also missing the source files, you have often to pause the video to code along and then check if you did as Kal suggested. I found that part a bit annoying.

I would have appreciated a focus on crafting beautiful websites and maybe at least a "state of the art" html+css+js source, just to have a solid starting point .

But i mean, this course is huge and it has a lot of material and since you can have it for 12 usd, what the hell, just thank you kalob so far :D

I came here from Angela Yu's "2021" bootcamp, because while I liked Angela, that course is very outdated even though it is advertised as updated for 2021. 

Great news if you're in a similar situation or unsure which bootcamp to choose - this course actually is current for 2021. If you're wondering if that matters, yes it does! 

I waited a while to review this course to make sure I wasn't about to sit through outdated Bootstrap or JavaScript again, and I'm very happy to report that so far this course is awesome! Great teacher, current material, and easy to follow along while also challenging you.

I'll update this later if needed, but I don't think I'll need to. Absolutely worth the price!

results.content: This course is very informative, it's nicely paced, and truly for people of different levels of expertise. The only issue is that I wish the course had something similar to worksheets, so that we could get that repetitious practice. However, Kalob does insist on research being most important skill within the dev industry, which I can definitely agree with, but as a student, I also believe that worksheets/mock lessons that forces students to use what they've learned in an "controlled" environment would be awesome. Nonetheless the class is great, and I'd definitely recommend it to others.

results.content: I am the annoying student that asks a lot of questions and they were all answered within a day. This course is very thorough and the concepts are explained well. It may take me longer than I anticipated to finish it, but it will be worth it. As a complete beginner, I had no frame of reference for all the topics covered. It would have been a lot easier if the instructor used more analogies to common life experiences to help understand concepts. There are also some gaps. For example in JS201, in explaining the final concept he refers to something that was not covered yet. I understand that I can google concepts, but I purchased this course so my learning would be more streamlined instead of piecemeal. I'm close to finishing the JS201 course, and I do not feel confident in my front end abilities to be able to do this as a career. So far I have had to supplement my learning significantly with resources outside of the course. It is better than I expected, but still not quite what I was hoping for.

results.content: The instructor is good, speaks clearly and (70% of the time) explains everything well. He is clearly knowledgeable and skilled. Questions are answered super promptly, which really helps. The problem is the curriculum and content. So I've been exploring this course over the past month or so and I've realized two things that have frustrated me to no end. 1. There is no continuity in the levels. Level 201 only sometimes builds on level 101. 2. The level is far too basic here. Level 101 is meant for absolute zero beginners and level 201 is for those getting started but with a bit of previous background. So, also beginners. If you already know anything about any of the languages, you're going to get really bored. I was watching videos here at X2 and I was still bored. I made the mistake of buying this course, thinking I'm getting 40 hours of content.. The content is so basic, you're not actually getting that much out of it. There is a lot of irrelevant extras that distract from the learning. As an example, Django 101 is fine with mostly good explanations. But Django 201 starts again from the beginning, only without explanations. Unfortunately, even when it gets complicated, there explanations are lacking. For some reason Django 201 also includes Tailwind, a good tool to learn, but not while you're trying to figure out Django. Django 201 also involves Ajax. Good tool, but it's an unnecessary segue. I think I may have enjoyed his course if I was starting from zero. My main recommendation being an educator myself is build a curriculum and remake the materials. Otherwise, it's very demotivating. Good luck guys, I'm sure you'll figure it out.

response.content: Hi Yuri, sorry to hear you disliked this bootcamp so much. Sounds like you aren't the right student for this course to begin with, you're too advanced for an A-Z bootcamp. Your projects were great, and you asked awesome questions! Topics like Django 201 we cannot assume everyone knows everything from Django 101. Not everyone starts at the 101 level, so we can't assume anything. And a large framework like Django has too many things to learn that differ from person to person, so nothing can be assumed. We did A LOT of market research around the way this course was setup (hundreds of hours) and this was the best approach for most people of all skill levels. This bootcamp is designed to develop your coding skills to the point where you can land a job. I think your feedback for Kalob is a bit harsh and inaccurate, and about 400+ other people on Udemy would likely agree with me. Thank you for taking the time to try out this bootcamp and giving your feedback, that's valuable to us. Good luck out there, Yuri!

results.content: I went as far as I could with this course. It is quite possibly the worst course I've ever taken. He tells you to do things, then in the next lesson, tells you that isn't really the right way to do it, and shows you another way, then says that isn't really the best way, either. So, you're basically learning bad habits, first, before he tells you best practice. Also, he has students trying to do advanced work, before giving a solid foundation, and without the benefit of learning things like flex, bootstrap, etc, first. I am a coder, and I took the course in hopes of being able to recommend a starting point to some friends who want to learn web development. This won't be the course I recommend. I had high hopes, but I think Mosh Hamedani is 100% better.

response.content: Hi Coding Queen. Sorry you had a bad experience. For the things we tell people to learn and then don't do, it's because there's an order of operations. You can't learn CSS Flexbox or CSS Grid without knowing HTML, which means learning tables (and those are still used on government sites and email templates, so it's applicable). That was just an example, but the history of each feature is important to understand as well. We've only received one other review along the lines of yours, out of the HUNDREDS of reviews we've recieved so far. So I'm going to venture a guess that you had preconceived ideas of how to teach a course before you even entered this course — OR that you aren't the target demographic for this course but decided to jump in anyway. Regardless, sorry to hear you didn't enjoy this course.

results.content:
I am a beginner (literally started 2 weeks ago). I have taken a few free and paid courses, and I have learned more in the first 24 hours with Kalob, than I have in the last 2 weeks. If you are new to coding and have no idea about anything, this is right for you. If you have some experience, it may be too slow, but you can jump to the course that fits you. He structured it in "101, 102, 103" categories. If you have seen videos or taken any sort of lesson, there is an assumption, even with the beginner lessons (i.e. "ok welcome, let's nest the

we just learned." but wtf is a nest?! Kalob literally explains what everything is and gives an analogy/metaphor. so far I am happy.
